articles.headline: New Louisiana Governor Pierces Brazen Style of Business as Usual
articles.snippet: An extensive package of ethics bills passed six weeks into the term of Gov. Bobby Jindal, signaling a cultural shift.
articles.abstract: An extensive package of ethics bills passed six weeks into the term of Gov. Bobby Jindal, signaling a cultural shift.
articles.lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La.  Downstairs, legislators gnashed their teeth, while upstairs at the Capitol here this week, the new governor claimed victory against the old customs down below.

articles.headline: Cash-Rich, Publicity-Shy, Abu Dhabi Fund Draws Scrutiny
articles.snippet: After decades in the shadows, the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority is turning heads by making high-profile investments across the globe.
articles.abstract: After decades in the shadows, the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority is turning heads by making high-profile investments across the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Abu Dhabi has about 9 percent of the world’s oil and 0.02 percent of its population. The result is a surfeit of petrodollars, much of which is funneled into a secretive, government-controlled investment fund that is helping to shift the balance of power in the financial world.

articles.headline: William F. Buckley Jr., 82, Dies; Sesquipedalian Spark of Right
articles.snippet: Mr. Buckley marshaled polysyllabic exuberance and a refined, perspicacious mind to elevate conservatism to the center of American political discourse.
articles.abstract: Mr. Buckley marshaled polysyllabic exuberance and a refined, perspicacious mind to elevate conservatism to the center of American political discourse.
articles.lead_paragraph: William F. Buckley Jr., who marshaled polysyllabic exuberance, arched eyebrows and a refined, perspicacious mind to elevate conservatism to the center of American political discourse, died on Wednesday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 82.

articles.headline: A Lender Halts U.S.-Backed Student Loans
articles.snippet: The Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency announced Wednesday that it would suspend making federal-guaranteed loans starting early next month.
articles.abstract: The Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency announced Wednesday that it would suspend making federal-guaranteed loans starting early next month.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency, one of the nation’s largest student loan operations, announced Wednesday that it would suspend making federal-guaranteed loans starting early next month.

articles.headline: Twists in Chain of Supplies for Blood Drug
articles.snippet: Differing statements from the factory owner and traders highlight the difficulty of tracing the supply chain in China for the blood-thinner heparin.
articles.abstract: Differing statements from the factory owner and traders highlight the difficulty of tracing the supply chain in China for the blood-thinner heparin.
articles.lead_paragraph: RUGAO, China  With reports of more than 400 patients in the United States suffering serious complications after receiving the blood-thinner heparin, American investigators are trying to determine whether the raw material for the drug, made from pig intestines, became contaminated on the journey that begins in the slaughterhouses of China.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Walt Bogdanich

articles.headline: Humane Society Sues U.S. in Cattle Case
articles.snippet: The Humane Society sued the Agriculture Department on Wednesday for creating a “loophole” that it said is permitting potentially sick cows into the food supply.
articles.abstract: The Humane Society sued the Agriculture Department on Wednesday for creating a “loophole” that it said is permitting potentially sick cows into the food supply.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Humane Society of the United States sued the Agriculture Department on Wednesday for creating a “loophole” that it said is permitting potentially sick cows into the food supply.

articles.headline: Federal Regulators to Ease Rules on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
articles.snippet: In a move that could help the housing market, a federal regulator said that it was removing limits on the investment portfolios of the two large mortgage buyers.
articles.abstract: In a move that could help the housing market, a federal regulator said that it was removing limits on the investment portfolios of the two large mortgage buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the biggest buyers of American home mortgages, will remove limits on the amount of loans and securities the companies can own, a step that could help bolster the weakening housing market.

articles.headline: Bernanke Says Sagging Growth Is Chief Concern
articles.snippet: The chairman of the Federal Reserve signaled his readiness to bolster the economy with cheaper money, though inflation is picking up speed.
articles.abstract: The chairman of the Federal Reserve signaled his readiness to bolster the economy with cheaper money, though inflation is picking up speed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, signaled his readiness on Wednesday to bolster the economy with cheaper money even though inflation is picking up speed.

articles.headline: Putin’s Anointed Heir Shows Hints of Less Icy Style
articles.snippet: Dmitri A. Medvedev, chosen by President Vladimir V. Putin to be Russia’s next leader, is crafting his own image.
articles.abstract: Dmitri A. Medvedev, chosen by President Vladimir V. Putin to be Russia’s next leader, is crafting his own image.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALABINO, Russia  Dmitri A. Medvedev, the man chosen to be the next Russian president, sat surrounded by soldiers. It was Feb. 23, Defenders of the Motherland Day, and Mr. Medvedev had traveled to the parade grounds of the Tamanskaya Motorized Rifle Division outside Moscow.
